Green Grapes.description: The fruit makes a popular snack, both because of its sweet flavor and because you can eat it whole without making a mess. Vineyards use the highest quality form of the green grape to make the most pristine white wines.

Green Olive.name: Green Olive
Green Olive.description: Green olives are picked when they have grown to full size, while still unripe. They can usually be found in shades from green to yellow. Olives are usually fermented to preserve them for a longer period of time and they generally end up being eaten as a healthy snack.

Green Pepper.name: Green Pepper
Green Pepper.description: The bell pepper usually comes in multiple colors, mainly green, yellow, and red, but purple, pink or white are not uncommon either. They are mainly referred to as sweet peppers. They can be garnished on multiple dishes, however, the most common use they have is in salads as an ingredient

Green Salad.name: Grüner Salat
Green Salad.description: Der Grüne Salat besteht aus lokal verfügbarem Gemüse wie zum Beispiel Zwiebeln, Gurken, Radieschen, Blattsalat, Spinat, Kohl und anderen.

Green Shadow.name: Green Shadow
Green Shadow.description: A butchered product of incorrectly mixing any potion that provides a form of invisibility. The skin starts to go chameleonic to a form, changing color to match its suroundings, however, the effect is slow to set in and it takes a bit of time up until you're fully "blended" with your background.

Green Soldier Bug.name: Green Soldier Bug
Green Soldier Bug.description: Green Soldier Bug, commonly referred to as the stink bug, emits a foul odor when crushed and poses a serious threat to crops like aubergines and tomatoes. Fortunately, unlike the Green Summer beetle, this critter can be managed effectively by hens and ducks, which help control their numbers without harming any of the crop.

Green Summer Beetle.name: Green Summer Beetle
Green Summer Beetle.description: Green Summer beetles become a problem during the growing season, harming both gardens and crops. These beetles target ripe or fermenting fruits like figs, grapes, and berries. Every summer, many common folk try to include wormwood in their planting cycle as it mostly behaves as an insect repellent.

Grilled Ribs.name: Grilled Ribs
Grilled Ribs.description: Fall-off-the-bone ribs, coated in sweet and tangy homemade sauces, are a beloved favorite at most taverns, often served for events or celebrations, and eagerly enjoyed by adventurers returning triumphant from their quests or missions.

Grilled Steak.name: Grilled Steak
Grilled Steak.description: A meticulously cooked slice of premium meat, often beef, cooked with precision and often with a side by your choice of fresh greens or soft mashed potatoes.

Grinder.name: Grinder
Grinder.description: A wooden contraption made with finely crafted and durable iron cogwheels is designed to reduce materials into a fine powder. A crank allows for easy operation. Though it originally served as an alternative to the traditional mortar and pestle, it is now primarily used by taverns to quickly grind dried pepper.

Grog.name: Grog
Grog.description: Grog is basically rum diluted with water. During expeditions to newly found lands, ship captains water down barrels of rum to keep the crew content while stretching their limited supplies over an extended period. This approach helped maintain high morale on long voyages where fresh provisions were scarce.

Hair Pin.name: Hair Pin
Hair Pin.description: A designer hairpin crafted with small gemstones to represent high status. It is made in such a way that, when it holds the hair, it exudes elegance and style, or to simply signal membership in the high noble class. These are primarily made by experienced jewelers and only on very high-priced commissions.

Hambergite.name: Hambergite
Hambergite.description: Hambergite is typically colorless or faintly blue. Despite being categorized as a semi-precious gem, it is more valued for its applications in lighting. It is commonly used in lamps to enhance the brightness of candles and other light sources, whether they are conventional or by arcane means.

Hand Axe.name: Hand Axe
Hand Axe.description: The go-to axe for various applications, it proves its usefulness as a camping tool for felling small trees, splitting kindling, and preparing firewood. Craftsmen appreciate its finesse in cutting wood to size and creating intricate patterns on furniture.

Hand Cart.name: Hand Cart
Hand Cart.description: The all-round tool for transporting items where they are needed. It can be used to transport feed for animals, large objects like planks, or carry fruits from orchards, all while remaining lightweight, making it a must-have tool on most farms.

Hand Drill.name: Hand Drill
Hand Drill.description: Functioning as a manual tool, a hand drill transforms and magnifies the circular motion of the crank into the rotation of a drill chuck. The tool includes a cranking handle that turns pinion gears on the main shaft, with a chuck at the end designed to secure a drill bit. This versatile tool finds common use among masons, carpenters, leatherworkers, and even blacksmiths, facilitating the drilling of fine holes in hard materials such as wood, hard leather, stone, soft metals, or even bones.

Hand Saw.name: Hand Saw
Hand Saw.description: With a wide range of applications, hand saws are the go-to tools for tasks like roughly cutting wood and logs, as well as making intricate curved cuts in wood. Whether used in professional trades or by the commoner for projects at home or in the garden, they prove to be indispensable tools.

Hand Truck.name: Hand Truck
Hand Truck.description: A hand truck, also referred to as a hand cart, comes with long handles is perfect for moving heavy items like barrels and furniture. It is frequently used by inns, taverns, and bakeries to facilitate daily restocking from the market.

Hard Candy.name: Hard Candy
Hard Candy.description: Hard candy has traditionally been regarded as a form of medicine, provided by herbalists to soothe stomach pains or alleviate sore throats. However, in more recent times, additional sugar and fruit have been incorporated into its recipe, quickly making it a favorite among young commoners.

Hardtack.name: Hardtack
Hardtack.description: Hardtack, made from flour, water, and salt, is known for its long shelf life. Due to its affordability and durability, it serves as a staple sustenance during long sea voyages and military campaigns, where most other foods are scarce.

Harunite.name: Harunite
Harunite.description: Hambergite is typically colorless or faintly blue. Despite being categorized as a semi-precious gem, it is more valued for its applications in lighting. It is commonly used in lamps to enhance the brightness of candles and other light sources, whether they are conventional or by arcane means.

Hazelnut.name: Hazelnut
Hazelnut.description: Hazelnuts get their name from their color, hazel. Sometimes they are also referred to as cobnuts or filberts. The nuts are used in cakes or as crumble toppings, however, if grounded they can also be used as flour for baking.

Heart.name: Heart
Heart.description: Looks like a stage prop, doesn’t it? Too shiny, too perfect, the sort of thing you’d expect dangling from a street conjurer’s sleeve. Yet hold one in your palm and you’ll swear it thrums against your skin, slow, steady, like the echo of your own chest. I’ve seen hardened mercenaries drop the thing lika a curse, as if they’d grabbed a live rat.

Hellgrammite.name: Hellgrammite
Hellgrammite.description: Hellgrammites are the perfect fishing bait across the realms, known to attract a wide range of fish including panfish, perch, pickerel, channel catfish, and especially bass. When fishing in deeper water or near heavy structures like submerged logs, tree roots, large rocks, or boat docks, they are thought to be particularly successful at drawing in the big catches, however, quite intimidating to look at.

Hematite.name: Hematite
Hematite.description: It is usually found with iron veins. Depending on its color when mined, it's mainly used to make red and brown pigments. On rare occasions, it is used for magical purposes, as it is assumed that this gem is linked to blood and life force. Used in the healing arts and necromancy

Henbane.name: Henbane
Henbane.description: The Henbane, also known as the Witches Plant, is a highly toxic plant, similar to the nightshade, however, herbalists use it, in combination with a plethora of other plants, to create anesthetic for sale for any medical practitioners. The Henbane is also a ritualistic herb, being used by magicians and healers in ritual purifications by smoke as well as in the preparation of concoctions, love philters, and 'flying ointments'.

Herring.name: Herring
Herring.description: Herrings can be fished in a variety of ways, from setting bait directly in the water and using nets to capture them in large batches, to more traditional rod fishing. Once caught, herrings are stored in numerous ways, with regional recipes that include raw, fermented, pickled, or salted varieties, as well as smoked or preserved through other methods.

Hexagonite.name: Hexagonite
Hexagonite.description: Hexagonite is an interesting gemstone, distinguished by its hexagonal shape when unearthed, which inspired its name. These gems are often sewn into clothing for social events, symbolically representing eligibility for marriage, particularly for bachelors.

Hickory Log.name: Hickory Log
Hickory Log.description: One of the most sought after types of wood. Used in most construction projects.

Hickory Plank.name: Hickory Plank
Hickory Plank.description: This specific light-colored wood is widely used for tools like hammers, picks, axes, wheels, ladders, flooring, and furniture.

Hog.name: Hog
Hog.description: Referred to as the hog, more commonly known as pig or sow in husbandry, this animal holds a prominent position as one of the most farmed for its meat. It serves as a vital resource in the production of sausages, gammon, bacon, ham, and various other food items.

Homemade Counteractant.name: Homemade Counteractant
Homemade Counteractant.description: Some of the commoners use quite a bit of lemon in creating these solutions, with other materials that they can find, which in return might have some adverse reactions. Sometimes leading to blindness or skin diseases after the concoction explodes or has other unforeseen and unfortunate side-effects, however, it's still common practice to create your own as the price for a store bought one is usually outside what a regular commoner can afford. Alchemists try to provide warnings of these issues, however, they mostly fall on deaf ears.

Honey.name: Honey
Honey.description: Honey, the sweet and viscous substance produced by honey bees, is commonly cultivated by many monasteries. Stored within the hive, honey bees construct honeycomb structures made from wax to contain the honey. Additionally, beeswax candles, derived from the honeycomb, are frequently used for lighting homes.

Honey Cookies.name: Honey Cookies
Honey Cookies.description: These types of cookies, made with honey, tend to have a fluffier texture and sweeter taste. Due to their affordability, filling nature, and extended shelf life, most taverns keep them in stock for sale at all times.

Honeycomb Cake.name: Honeycomb Cake
Honeycomb Cake.description: Despite its name, the Honeycomb Cake does not contain any honey. However, most bakers shape it into a honeycomb pattern to enhance its appeal. Due to its exotic ingredients, this cake remains unfamiliar to many commoners. It requires pandan, coconut milk, and coconut oil, which can be difficult to find depending on the region.

Horn.name: Horn
Horn.description: The horn is often regarded as the predecessor to both the trumpet and the cornet. While it is primarily made from brass, there are also variants crafted from bone, which are particularly favored in remote, cold, or mountainous regions. They can be used for music, drive for battles, or alarms.

Horseshoe.name: Horseshoe
Horseshoe.description: In certain regions, horseshoes are seen as a harbinger of good luck, while in others, they symbolize advanced industry. Typically crafted from steel, the choice of material may vary depending on metal availability in specific areas, including options like bronze, copper, or iron. In exceptionally uncommon cases, materials such as hide, leather, or even wood are considered.

Horsetail.name: Horsetail
Horsetail.description: Horsetail is a common herb that has been used by herbalists for centuries to treat a variety of ailments, including bleeding, wounds, colds, and hay fever. It grows in many parts of the world and is considered poisonous to sheep and cattle, although it is safe for the common folk to consume in small amounts.

Hosho.name: Hosho
Hosho.description: The hosho is a rattle instrument crafted from a wild orange known as damba, with sticks used to tie it together and filled with hota seeds or pebbles. Its unique shape produces a sharp, distinctive sound that often cuts through the music of other instruments.

Hot Punch.name: Hot Punch
Hot Punch.description: Referred to either as a forging punch or hot punch, this tool is primarily utilized for cutting or punching through metal to shape and secure it. Moreover, it lends itself to forming impressions or designs, making it a choice for the more discerning customers.

Hot Spiced Raspberry Cider.name: Hot Spiced Raspberry Cider
Hot Spiced Raspberry Cider.description: Considered by most a traditional winter drink with the sweet addition of fruit. Its inviting aroma will fill the taverns, while the warm cider keeps everyone cozy during cold season evenings. Although multiple ingredients can be used in its making, two remain constant, mainly rum and raspberry cider. Additions such as maple syrup, cardamom, ginger, peppercorns, cloves, or cinnamon are common additions that give it a stronger flavor and seasonal charm.

Hugger of Faces.name: Hugger of Faces
Hugger of Faces.description: According to some rare studies, the creature’s body wraps tightly to the face, while its tail coils around the neck, to an unknown purpose. However, due to limited documentation of them, their purpose remains uncertain. No living specimens have ever been discovered, only the ocassional exoskeleton shells. Analysis of these shells has led to the theory that the creature's blood is highly acidic as it is capable of dissolving most substances.

Humanoid Skull.name: Humanoid Skull
Humanoid Skull.description: The humanoid skulls have limited fringe uses. They usually are in demand by medical practitioners for better a understanding of medicine. Ritualistic needs, are mainly used as components, or, added at the end of staves for ornamental purposes. Or, by the magical practitioners for what some might consider extreme arcane arts. Another rare usage is for the decoration of some more eccentric lords in their expansive manors.

Huni Guitar.name: Huni Guitar
Huni Guitar.description: Unlike a regular guitar, this instrument has a square shape that affects its acoustics. The sound hole creates a slight reverb effect on the strings, giving the guitar a distinctive tone compared to other stringed instruments. Bards often include these guitars in musical ensembles because of their unique sound.

Hunter's Mark.name: Hunter's Mark
Hunter's Mark.description: This uniquely shaped coin is given by nobles to hunters as identification for permission to hunt on their land, after some form of payment has been made. Once the hunt is complete, the hunter returns the coin to the noble and may choose to sell the hunt directly to them. Typically, the hunter and noble will agree to a percentage of the hunt's profits beforehand. The coin can also be sold to merchant banks at a higher price, freeing the noble to attend to other matters.

Hurdy-Gurdy.name: Hurdy-Gurdy
Hurdy-Gurdy.description: The hurdy-gurdy is a string instrument that creates sound by using a hand-crank-turned, round rosined wheel that rubs against the strings. Melodies are produced on a keyboard, that presses tangents against one or more strings to alter their pitch. This unique mechanism allows for a continuous melody while notes are played, giving the instrument its characteristic sound.

Hyacinth.name: Hyacinth
Hyacinth.description: Hyacinth, alternatively called Jacinth or Flamegem depending on where it's found, is a rare gem prized for its vibrant, fiery orange color. Known for its hardness and durability akin to sapphire and ruby, its unique affinity for fire lends its significance to arcane rituals and applications.

Hyalite.name: Hyalite
Hyalite.description: Hyalite, a milky form of quartz, is mainly utilized for crafting crystal balls. It is particularly favored by novice practitioners of arcane arts and mystical disciplines, leading schools to procure hyalite in large quantities.

Hydrophane.name: Hydrophane
Hydrophane.description: This semi-precious stone was commonly employed in inlay work or cut into cabochons for jewelry. In its dry state, it appeared plain and opaque, typically displaying an ivory or frosty-white color. However, when submerged in water, it underwent a remarkable transformation, becoming transparent and exhibiting a rainbow-like iridescence akin to a prism.

Hypersthene.name: Hypersthene
Hypersthene.description: This semi-precious stone displays hues ranging from green, red, and blue, to silver, and is notable for its complete opacity, a rarity among gemstones. Due to its unique characteristics, it fetches a premium price and is primarily utilized to embellish both furniture and clothing.

Idicolite.name: Idicolite
Idicolite.description: Often mistaken for sapphire, this gemstone is actually a variant of tourmaline. Despite attempts by unscrupulous merchants to pass it off as the more valuable sapphire, its discernible, slightly less vibrant color serves as a telltale sign to those with a trained eye.

Invitation.name: Invitation
Invitation.description: Invitations are often used for weddings, official events, or to gain access to the count's court. They vary greatly in style, ranging from highly formal to personal, and from luxurious to official. It’s typically difficult to know exactly what kind of event awaits until the invitation is opened.

Iol.name: Iol
Iol.description: A violet color stone, sometimes referred to as Iolite. Is usually cut into gemstone facets and is used in all types of jewelry, especially rings.

Iris Agate.name: Iris Agate
Iris Agate.description: This stone is a finely-banded and usually colorless agate, however, when cut properly, it displays an amazing show of colors on its surface, sometimes also referred to as "Rainbow Agate"

Iron Ingot.name: Iron Ingot
Iron Ingot.description: Iron Ingots can be used by skilled blacksmiths to craft nails, corner wedges, locks, flint, iron swords, manacles, shovels, pickaxes, and axes. They also produce iron beams, brackets, and supports to reinforce buildings and bridges, ensuring their longevity. Craftsmen use iron in furniture manufacturing, and on some rare occassion it is incorporated in jewlery.

Iron Ore.name: Iron Ore
Iron Ore.description: Iron Ore is one of the more abundant ores that can be found in both underground and mountainous regions. The quality of the iron can vary wildly depending on where it is located. Most of the iron gets transformed into pig iron which is the main material that goes into the forges to manufacture steel. Iron ore is a vital trade good, even more so than gold, with kingdoms leveraging their deposits to dominate commerce.

Ironwood Log.name: Ironwood Log
Ironwood Log.description:
"We call it Ironwood, but it usually has its own name depending on the region. The folks at the lumber mills hate this type of wood, as almost every time they have to replace their main blade. Not to mention if anyone wants lumber from it they need to have a proper amount of gold too. It is very resilient!"

Ironwood comes in several colors, ranging from red to gray to bright browns, depending on the region where it was harvested. It is mainly used as firewood as it burns very slowly. When used in furniture, it is usually  only used for small decorative add-ons, as most woodworker tools are not efficient in carving it.

Jackhammer.name: Jackhammer
Jackhammer.description: Jackhammer is a pneumatic, steam-powered, or arcano-mechanical tool that combines a hammer directly with a chisel. It was created specifically to chisel out harder stones that do not require finesse to break into smaller pieces for easier transportation.

Jade.name: Jade
Jade.description: Its primary form is called Jadeite, after cutting, it's mainly used in ornamental sculptures and figurines. Musicians of all kinds believed that if they wore Jade, they would improve their musical prowess

Jargoon.name: Jargoon
Jargoon.description: Jargoons are highly valued for their deep red color and radiant shine, resembling rubies. There are rumors that this specific gem can either project arcane projectiles or prevent creatures of the night from shifting out of their human form, but further research is required to confirm these claims.

Jasper.name: Jasper
Jasper.description: Each Jasper gemstone is assumed to be unique, as every gemstone has singular pattern, ranging from spotted patterns to ringed, or stripped. In days past it was regarded as a valuable stone, now is mainly used by alchemists and herbalists to create antidotes and magical poisons, because the stones proprieties assist in neutralizing and protecting from poison.

Jasper Ring.name: Jasper Ring
Jasper Ring.description: The Jasper Ring is crafted from a single solid piece of jasper, shaped by experienced gemcutters with exceptional skill and precision. Thanks to its beautiful coloring and vibrant polish, it attracts the attention of many commoners seeking a ring that match their fingers. It is offered at a modest price, making it highly accessible to people from all walks of life.

Jet.name: Jet
Jet.description: Jet, a deep black gemstone, is sufficiently hard to be faceted and is often utilized in straightforward pendants or as a component in clothing and furniture. In cultural practices across various regions, wearing Jet-adorned clothing signifies themes of sorrow and mourning.

Jewelry box.name: Jewelry box
Jewelry box.description: Jewelry boxes are essential in protecting delicate pieces from damage. While diamonds, being the hardest natural material, can scratch softer gemstones like opals and pearls, they can also mark softer metals like gold. But in general, the regular jewelry boxes provide a dedicated space for jewelry in a centralized storage, reducing the chances of misplacement or loss.

Kala Namak.name: Kala Namak
Kala Namak.description: Kala Namak, or black salt, is both mined and crafted by alchemists. The crafting process involves sealing raw salts in ceramic jars with charcoal and adding harad seeds, amla, bahera, babul bark, or natron before firing them in a furnace for 24 hours. The resulting salt is brownish-pink to dark violet in color when ungrounded.

Kinnor.name: Kinnor
Kinnor.description: The kinnor resembles the lyre in shape, but it is typically held from the end and strummed like a lute. Unlike the lyre, where fingerpicking is common, the kinnor uses a metal rod as a pick, allowing for the production of prolonged notes and a distinct sound.

Kiwifruit.name: Kiwifruit
Kiwifruit.description: Often shortened to Kiwi, a well sought after fruit. It can be eaten raw, made into juices, used in baked goods, fruit salads, prepared with meat or used as a garnish.

Kompot.name: Kompot
Kompot.description: Also more commonly known as stewed fruit, this is a very simple recipe that involves only water, sugar, and fruit. Everything is thrown into a pot, boiled, bottled, and served cold. This beverage is made by inns and bakeries alike, using any leftover fruit they have, as the concoction has a very long shelf life when completed.

Kornerupine.name: Kornerupine
Kornerupine.description: Kornerupine is found in green or brown translucent crystals that are sufficiently hard to be cut into solid faceted gems of medium size. The green variety of kornerupine is particularly notable for its arcane ability to record sounds and noises.

Kurnarac.name: Kurnarac
Kurnarac.description: Deep within the cave, the Kurnarac seed is carefully planted. With a precise shot from the slingshot or a modified crossbow, it lands against the ceiling, sticking fast. Years pass, and once a small seed begins to grow, its upside-down tree-like form takes shape as its spiky bark gradually thickens. The cold, damp cave becomes the perfect environment for a steady, almost imperceptible growth. Over the decades, its roots stretch downward, like a stalactite forming, until the Kurnarac matures, its bark now a thick, protective shell. The need for harvesting fades, as the plant naturally preserves its Wall Meat within, offering sustenance that will last indefinitely.

Kyanite.name: Kyanite
Kyanite.description: Kyanite is generally used in the creation of ceramic dishware, mainly due to its distinctive beautiful blue colors. It is a gemstone that blends easily with many other materials under heat. It can also be ground into a fine powder to make high-quality inks.

Ladder.name: Ladder
Ladder.description: The ladder is a simple yet essential tool for reaching elevated areas. Whether in libraries, homes, farms, barns, or used by firefighters to rescue people from high places, ladders are used in various environments for essential tasks.

Ladybug.name: Ladybug
Ladybug.description: Ladybugs, associated with luck due to their spots, always follow a plentiful harvest. Common folk love them because they eat aphids and other plant pests, keeping the crops safe. The kids love to look at them and have a small song to accompany it, used to count the spots on the ladybug, believing they bring them long lasting luck.

Lake Trout.name: Lake Trout
Lake Trout.description: Lake Trout live in cool, well-oxygenated streams and lakes. They can be fished using a variety of baits, with drifting whole earthworms, as well as small minnows and mealworms. A unique feature of the lake trout is its unique coloration before being caught, the fish displays vibrant rainbow-like hues, but these colors fade once it is removed from the water.

Lantern Jack.name: Lantern Jack
Lantern Jack.description: Ah, the Lantern Jack. No market cart nor tavern stoop feels quite right during Red Harvest without one grinning back at you. At its simplest, it’s just a hollowed pumpkin with eyes and a mouth carved in, a candle guttering inside. Yet there’s something more to them than vegetables and wax. Stand in a village square at dusk, the chill coming down, and those rows of leering faces look near alive, like a crowd watching you from the dark.

Lapis Lazuli.name: Lapis Lazuli
Lapis Lazuli.description: A blue opaque gemstone, it is usually used as ornamentation for rings, bracelets, pendants, or talismans. Due to its specific color sometimes it is carved in artistic shapes, such as griffons, scarabs, or even unicorns.

Last Will.name: Last Will
Last Will.description: Usually made as a transfer of wealth and land, enforced by a nearby lord or kingdom, for the assets to be distributed as instructed. Some wills are not for wealth distribution but serve as a way to communicate final thoughts, hopes, or legacies, sometimes with a personal touch through the aid of a bard or clergy.

Laterite.name: Laterite
Laterite.description: Laterite is mainly used in making bricks, but it is used in all types of paint, primers, powders, and coatings, among other things. Used as a pigment in tiles, floor tiles, flooring products, ceramics, pottery, and many other items involving tiles and ceramics.

Latratite.name: Latratite
Latratite.description: On the rarest of occasions, it is referred to as the "Gem of the Divines," and not many of its kind have been discovered throughout history. It is speculated that, if ingested, the consumer will gain the ability to persuade everyone in their path. However, the limited knowledge we have of Latratite does not provide any information on its potential side effects. Rumor has it that ingesting this gem will make your skin emanate a faint blue glow, your eyes and hair perpetually change shades until they reach a pure gold color. Those coming with contact with someone who has ingested Latratite will only tell the truth or be easily coerced. However, when the effect dissipates, the user will not remember the event, but others will remember what was said to them.

Laudanum.name: Laudanum
Laudanum.description: Laudanum is a highly prized tincture created by skilled alchemists. It has a reddish-brown color and a bitter taste. Its main ingredients include breadseed poppy, saffron, crushed pearls, and a strong alcohol. It is believed to be effective in treating a range of ailments, including severe coughs and pains.

Laurel.name: Laurel
Laurel.description: The Laurel comes from an evergreen shrub or small tree, that is usually kept potted at a herbalist's store. The medicinal properties of the Laurel make it one of the most coveted plants by all medicinal practitioners. It can be used in poultices, teas, as a rub, or direct medicine, for any kind of disease to any form of infection. It is also a symbol of status, in some regions laurel crowns are quite common, or a symbol of victory or achievement.

Lead.name: Lead
Lead.description:
"The weirdest stuff I’ve heard of it being used for is, funny enough, make-up, but I feel it can have better usage. Most cities that have any plumbing have it thanks to lead."

 

This specific metal is quite heavy and has a silvery appearance with a hint of blue. It's mainly used in ammunition due to it being heavy and resistant, plumbing and pipelines, as well as in fishing.

Lead Ingot.name: Lead Ingot
Lead Ingot.description: Through the realms, the lead ingot is a valuable commodity. Skilled craftsmen seek it out to make powerful bullets for their weapons. These bullets are then powered by magic so they can inflict a lot of damage on magical beasts or incorporeal beings. They are also used by alchemists to create potions and elixirs. The lead ingot is very valuable and versatile.

Leather Bedroll.name: Leather Bedroll
Leather Bedroll.description: The standard issue bedroll, made to be used in all types of regular or extreme weathers while traveling. It is usually fairly well isolated from the cold and rain. Under most common scenarios, a lot of patchwork is used to actually make them, and they are quite rarely made from one dedicated piece of leather.

Leather Scales.name: Leather Scales
Leather Scales.description: Leatherworkers usually make these specifically for leather scale armor or for equine saddle armors, made to take and dissipate the heaviest of blows. However, the process is quite tedious to make, and the unlucky, unskilled new hires get tasked to make these in huge quantities to hone the process of cutting leather accurately.

Leather Scroll.name: Leather Scroll
Leather Scroll.description: Leather scrolls in the regions with access to a lot of pelts replaced papyrus as the preferred writing material. They are usually made from sheep, goat, or calf skins that have been scraped to remove the hair, stretched, and dried on a frame. It is most often made by fastening several pieces together, with glue or thread.

Ledger.name: Ledger
Ledger.description: Businesses use specific ledgers to track purchases or sales or to store information. Depending on the store it can also contain additional information such as customers, traders, trade routes, or where the deepest cave exists. Prospectors use them to keep track of locations for ores. Herbalists tend to use them to track inventory, while a kingdom might store information on tax. As many ledgers exist there are as many uses.

Leek.name: Leek
Leek.description: Leeks are essential in summer salads, leek and potato soup, leek puree, and plain leek soup. They boast a mild, onion-like flavor and retain a crunchy, firm texture in their raw form. The edible portions of the leek are the white base of the leaves.

Leerfish.name: Leerfish
Leerfish.description: Leerfish, also known as Garrick in certain regions, is a fast-swimming predator found in warm coastal waters. Unlike many other fish species, it does not require specialized fishing gear, as it readily bites at a wide variety of lures and bait. This accessibility makes it a common catch among local fishers and commercial fishing fleets alike. Its slender frame provides tender fillets, which are often prepared as grilled steaks or simmered in rich, spiced stews.

Left Behind Note.name: Left Behind Note
Left Behind Note.description:
Me and the party thought coming here was a good idea. Now, I’m stuck in this room, and I don’t know what awaits me beyond the door - only that there are many.

If anyone finds this, please let my family know that I am alive, though I’ll be traveling far away. It may be some time before I can reach them again.

Consider this my final wish, should fate not favor me.

I hope your luck is better than my own.

Erne of Windfall

Lemon.name: Lemon
Lemon.description: The applications of regular lemons are close to limitless. They are used as cleaning products as they help with degreasing. In cooking they are used as an ingredient to sour foods for a bit of extra tang. One of the most famous pies is the Lemon pie. They are used in concoctions for skincare and sometimes local cures to help with different ailments. They can often be found in refreshing drinks

Lemongrass.name: Lemongrass
Lemongrass.description: Lemongrass is primarily used as a medicinal herb and in the production of perfumes, but it also has many culinary applications. Its citrusy flavor complements fish and most seafood dishes perfectly. Lemongrass is also commonly used in soups, marinades, salads, and vegetable pickling.

Lentils.name: Lentils
Lentils.description: Lentils can be soaked, fried, baked, or boiled. Lentils with husks remain whole with moderate cooking, while those without husks tend to disintegrate into thick purees, suitable for various dishes. They are used to prepare inexpensive and nutritious soups, often combined with chicken or pork, and cooked lentils are also a popular addition to salads.

Lesser Absinthe.name: Lesser Absinthe
Lesser Absinthe.description: Absinthe is traditionally prepared through the distillation of neutral alcohol with a blend of anise, wormwood, and fennel. The Lesser Absinthe variant includes an added touch of mint extract, which is believed to reduce the intensity of hallucinations often associated with the drink. However, the effects can vary greatly depending on the individual who consumes it.

Letter From a Loved One.name: Letter From a Loved One
Letter From a Loved One.description:
Hello dear,

We are happy to hear you are doing well, and the last coin you send back we finally we were able to fix the hole we had in the thatch in our kitchen.

The youngest finally came of age to be sent to the abbott to learn to read and write, and how to do so efficently, but our oldest, his eyes are getting darker as time goes, now they are like the deep sea, a deep blue that looks unnatural. If you look long enough you see things... Horrible things.

I am scared... When are you coming back? Please let it be soon.

With love,

Your Dandelion

Lettuce.name: Lettuce
Lettuce.description: Lettuce is most often used for salads, although it is also found in other kinds of food, such as soups and sandwiches.

Lifeline.name: Lifeline
Lifeline.description: Lifeline is a ring crafted by the most secluded underground folk, usually made in pairs, though larger sets are not unheard of. Its purpose is to keep in contact with friends or family. Primarily forged from iron or steel, the inscription on the inside contains the names of loved ones. With the aid of arcane knowledge, the ring forms a link to the others. When the text glows, it signals that the close family member or friend is still alive.

Lime.name: Lime
Lime.description: Limes have higher contents of sugars and acids than lemons do. Lime juice may be squeezed from fresh limes, or purchased in bottles in both unsweetened and sweetened varieties. Depending on the region they can also be pickled. It is a fruit sought after by sailors as it is known to settle the upset stomach on rough sea voyages, not to mention that it mixes quite well with rum.

Linen.name: Linen
Linen.description: A very strong and absorbent material, that is very comfortable to wear in hot weather and is widely used in textiles.

Liquid Malachite.name: Liquid Malachite
Liquid Malachite.description: Liquid Malachite is generally stored in a wooden container. When taken out of its container and coming in contact with metal, it quickly spreads, attaches, and hardens, but only temporarily. Historically, it was primarily utilized by militaristic tribal communities, as they didn't typically wear armor but rather used a thin woven metal cloth. However, its potential should not be underestimated, as even when combined with tin, the liquid malachite increases the strength and durability of materials to a level comparable to steel.

Liquid Solid Slate.name: Liquid Solid Slate
Liquid Solid Slate.description: Little is known about the process of liquefaction, however, when used as an alloy with another metal, it is said to be unbreakable. When struck by a weapon, an impenetrable shock-wave is created, pushing the weapon back. Due to its weight, it makes it difficult for people trying to move stealthily.

Living Book.name: Living Book
Living Book.description: The fable goes that it is a journal of sorts, said to be owned by a forgotten by time witch. At every solstice, the pages get erased, and new entries can be added. When new entries are added, and if specifically written as a journal, the book itself rolls its eyes as soon as something embarrassing is written in it.

Lobster.name: Lobster
Lobster.description: Lobsters live in all oceans, on rocky, sandy, or muddy bottoms from the shoreline to the deep sea. Lobsters, like some snails and spiders, have blue blood, which alchemists extract for use against some of the more common illnesses and to heal skin damaged by burns.

Lombart Wine.name: Lombart Wine
Lombart Wine.description: Lombart Wine is a renowned drink, manufactured and distributed across the realms by the Roklas Lombart winery. Known for its consistent quality and approachable price, it stands among the better wines available on the market. Its widespread availability, even in the most remote and secluded regions, often sparks more curiosity about the logistics behind its distribution than the wine itself.

Longbill Spearfish.name: Longbill Spearfish
Longbill Spearfish.description: Longbill Spearfish sometimes referred to as the Marlin, is a large fish primarily found in the open ocean. It is famously sought after as a trophy catch, often displayed on plaques in the halls of the wealthy. The chefs look in the market as it is also prized for its meat, which nobles consider a delicacy, commanding a hefty price in gold.

Longstraw.name: Longstraw
Longstraw.description: Longstraw is referred to the straw specifically grown for roof thatching. Longstraw is made from either water reed thatch or combed wheat, both of which are commonly used in roof thatching. They are preferred for roofing due to its extended life compared to traditional wood-based roofing materials.

Lover's Embrace.name: Lover's Embrace
Lover's Embrace.description: A couple of sweet gelatin tarts are usually made by boiling bones, removing them from the resulting liquid, and allowing it to cool, making it a gelatin like substance. The gelatin is then flavored with a mixture of fruits, citrus, and sugar until the taste from the bone residue dissipates. Due to its very sweet nature, it is only served as a treat for anniversaries or for newlywed couples.

Lyre.name: Lyre
Lyre.description: The lyre is one of the oldest string instruments, characterized by its yoke, which consists of two arms and a crossbar that projects horizontally from the body. While most lyres are plucked to produce sound, rarely, a number of them are designed to be bowed, adding to their versatility in music.

MIlk.name: MIlk
MIlk.description: Milk is a husbandry byproduct which usually comes from cows, goats, and sheep. It is a white, nutritious liquid often consumed as a beverage or used to make a variety of dairy products such as cheese, butter, and yogurt. Scholars believe it has magical properties that can strengthen bones to an ungodly degree.

Macaw.name: Macaw
Macaw.description: The Macaw, one of the rarer types of parrots, is highly favored by seafaring rogues. These birds keep a watchful eye on the crew, relay commands, and update the captain on the ship's activities while he rests.

Mackerel.name: Mackerel
Mackerel.description: Mackerel can be enjoyed raw, oven-cooked, fried, smoked, or salted with vinegar. Taverns often provide a variety of cooking options to cater to different clientele tastes.

Maguey Syrup.name: Maguey Syrup
Maguey Syrup.description: Maguey Syrup, also referred to as Agave Syrup or Agave Nectar, is primarily used as a sweetener and is a popular substitute for honey. Varieties of Maguey Syrup include Light agave, used in specific culinary dishes and beverages; Amber, known for its caramel notes and favored in drinks with bold flavors; and Dark agave syrup, often employed as a topping for pancakes or waffles, as a few examples.

Mahogany Log.name: Mahogany Log
Mahogany Log.description: Mahogany is a straight-grained, reddish-brown timber that is mainly harvested for the wood, found in most warmer climates, mainly tropical forests, and extremely rare. Some territories, have this specific wood outright banned for import as it tends to put a high economic pressure on the territory as it is also in high demand.

Mahogany Lumber.name: Mahogany Lumber
Mahogany Lumber.description: Mahogany is important lumber prized for its beauty, durability, and color, and tends to be the most prized type of lumber. It is used for paneling and to make furniture, boats, decorative pieces, musical instruments, and other items.

Maiden Voyage.name: Maiden Voyage
Maiden Voyage.description: Maiden voyage is the name given to the first trip that a ship makes after it has been launched, however, the drink bearing the same name is usually provided by the tavern-keeps as a drink to commemorate loved ones, after passing from the realm of the living. The drink is primarily jenever, a juniper-flavored strong gin with a mixture of corn wine.

Maidenhair.name: Maidenhair
Maidenhair.description: This herbal supplement is frequently recommended by herbalists and is mainly used to address blood disorders. It is also renowned for its ability to help keep your memory sharp.

Malachite.name: Malachite
Malachite.description: A popular mineral, mainly used for pigments, or to dye metals in a green tint while creating iron bars. Whitesmiths and Jewelers usually request high amounts of Malachite for their trade. It is rumored that Malachite in the ages past was used to prevent users from falling, however, the magical skill needed for the spell has been lost to time.

Malakim's Touch.name: Malakim's Touch
Malakim's Touch.description: Malakim's Touch is a cocktail made with a blend of multiple types of liquor, quite sweet in nature, it tempts drinkers into having more than they should. Only for them to find themselves the next morning, groaning in pain and begging the heavens and hells for mercy. It usually bears a red color due to the cherry and strawberry liquor that are used in high quantities.

Mallet.name: Mallet
Mallet.description: Wooden mallets are a staple in carpentry, serving to knock wooden pieces together, drive dowels, manipulate chisels, and apply pressure on joints. Notably, they stand apart from most metal hammers by preventing the deformation of the striking end of a metal tool.

Malrite.name: Malrite
Malrite.description: A black gemstone, no one knows where it is mined or how it is located, as it simply appears at market stalls or jeweler stores. When the owner of the stall or store is inquired about it, they have no clue how it ended up their inventory.

Mandarin.name: Mandarin
Mandarin.description: Mandarin orange fruits are small and usually a red-orange color. The skin is quite thin and peels rather easily. The skin can also be zested, a process which creates small strips of peel that are usually used to add flavor to different pastries and sweets such as pies, cakes, cookies, biscuits, chocolate, and many many others.

Manganese Brick.name: Manganese Brick
Manganese Brick.description: Manganese Bricks are not only used for their destructive flames but also for psychological warfare. When launched into enemy buildings and walls, they create intense heat and thick smoke, forcing defenders out of their strongholds. The horrible choking stench, coming from the charred brick, can linger for many hours, making it nearly impossible to reclaim the area.

Manganese Chips.name: Manganese Chips
Manganese Chips.description: Manganese Chips, after being mined, are rarely used by alchemists or herbalists in the production of potions or medicine, as well as in the creation of herbicides and brown paint. Their primary use is in the forging of a variety of important alloys to make them more resilient.

Mango.name: Mango
Mango.description: Depending on the tree it grows on, the mango fruit varies in size, shape, sweetness, skin color, and flesh color. The flesh can range from pale yellow to gold, green, or orange. In some regions, it is speculated to be the fruit of love. In other regions it is given as a token of friendship. Herbalists create a paste with honey, lemon, and mango as a cough syrup.

Mania potion.name: Mania potion
Mania potion.description: The vial gives off a solid gold glow, as it attracts you to consume it. If consumed you feel that the gods made a vow to protect you and you alone, and all should cower before you in shame and fear, however, this potion does not have any powerful effects it only gives the impression of grandeur.

Maple Log.name: Maple Log
Maple Log.description: Maple trees are usually in high demand in the spice industry because of their sap, syrup, and sugar that can be made.

Maple Lumber.name: Maple Lumber
Maple Lumber.description: The lumber is mainly used to make furniture and is the best choice for wooden flooring.

Maple Sap.name: Maple Sap
Maple Sap.description: Being one of the sweetest variants of sap, it can be used by brewmasters to create ales, or by tavern keeps to sweeten water, as a syrup, or even tea. Alchemists use it to create potions that make your aim true.

Maram.name: Maram
Maram.description: The maram is a percussion instrument found in various regions. It features a wooden cylinder with two skin heads on either end, which are tensioned with skin laces to create sound. This construction allows the maram to produce a rich, resonant tone when played to be used in a variety of musical situations such as traditional ceremonies to dance performances.

Marble.name: Marble
Marble.description: The favorite tool of skilled sculptors, marble, transforms thoughts and emotions into beautiful sculptures as they carve it. Polished to a shine, it earns the sculptor a hefty profit when sold. Marble is one of the heaviest and most resilient stones that can be bought with coin. Its elegance makes it a popular choice for nobility, who use it for indoor flooring and heavy furnishings.

Marjoram.name: Marjoram
Marjoram.description: Marjoram is quite similar to oregano but is a bit milder and sweeter, a lot of chefs use it for meats, stews, and sauces. Herbalists use it as a primer for any concoctions that help with runny nose, cough, common cold, other infections, and various digestion problems.

Marriage Band.name: Marriage Band
Marriage Band.description: Usually made out of gold, it is usually a religious symbol of bonding two in the eyes of a deity. The ring itself can be manufactured in multiple ways, with the addition of gems, inscriptions, or even alternative materials in the rare case that someone is allergic to gold or silver.

Mashed Potatoes.name: Mashed Potatoes
Mashed Potatoes.description: Mashed potatoes represent a classic staple in many cuisines. The process involves boiling potatoes and then mashing them into a soft paste often served as a side dish alongside various meats.

Mason Hammer.name: Mason Hammer
Mason Hammer.description: Commonly called brick hammers, mason's hammers are primarily designed for the precise breaking of bricks, rocks, pavers, or driving stakes. They feature one flat traditional face and, on the back, a short or long chisel-shaped blade. This design allows them to effectively chip off edges or small pieces of stone and cut brick masonry units without the need for a separate chisel.

Mead.name: Mead
Mead.description: Most monasteries keep up the traditions of mead making as a byproduct of beekeeping, especially in areas where grapes could not be grown, however, as long there's access to any form of honey, mead can be easily made. Most taverns simply import honey and begin the fermentation process to produce mead locally.

Meat of the Hunt.name: Meat of the Hunt
Meat of the Hunt.description: This dish features a cooked piece of game brought in by adventurers. The meats are usually not found on most tavern menus and are for the bravest patrons who are not afraid to experiment.

Mechanized Key.name: Mechanized Key
Mechanized Key.description: These types of keys are more like missing pieces in a complex engineered structure. They are called keys because when they are placed into their designated slots, they activate the mechanism of the structure. These keys are typically used for vaults, and only a very few are capable of crafting them.

Menu.name: Menu
Menu.description:
@UUID[Compendium.kctg-2e.kctg-2e.Item.FKpH0HjMlE2VJbM8]{Burger} - 8 cp (20% discount)

@UUID[Compendium.kctg-2e.kctg-2e.Item.6QEYPg65gmIDfDM6]{Caltabose} - Local Speciality - 4cp


@UUID[Compendium.kctg-2e.kctg-2e.Item.INzGIklfSqIhCHuw]{Bean Stew with Meat} - 5 cp
@UUID[Compendium.kctg-2e.kctg-2e.Item.iYLfDwgVhnNTV4zN]{Fish Soup} - 4 cp

King's Visit - Winter Solstice

Mercury / Cinnabar.name: Mercury / Cinnabar
Mercury / Cinnabar.description: Mercury is found in large quantities within cinnabar deposits and generally found in areas associated with volcanic activity and hot springs. This silvery-looking metal changes into liquid form at room temperature, making it unique among its metallic counterparts. Mercury is primarily used by alchemists to treat skin ailments, though its effects remain a topic of debate.

Metal Leaves.name: Metal Leaves
Metal Leaves.description: These are known as touchstone leaves, and are used by merchants or bank tellers to easily identify types of precious metals. The leaves themselves can be made out of gold, silver, platinum, or electrum, with various levels of purity. When testing a metal object, the leaves are scratched on a touchstone along with the object in question. Based on the residue they leave behind, it is possible to quickly identify the metal's purity or determine if it is a counterfeit.

Microlite.name: Microlite
Microlite.description: Microlite gems are small yet very hard, suitable for cutting into faceted gems used to adorn swords, armor, shields, and horse tack. Beyond their decorative uses, they also serve as a practical substitute for traditional squid or octopus ink.

Midnight Crappie.name: Midnight Crappie
Midnight Crappie.description: Midnight Crappie is a rare sight during the day, as it prefers the cool darkness of night to hunt for food. Fishermen seeking this specific catch rely on strategic lighting, using lanterns to mimic the glow of moonlight on the water. These sources of illumination lure the crappie out from their hiding spots among submerged trees and rocky outcrops, making them easier to catch.

Mimic Sandwich.name: Mimic Sandwich
Mimic Sandwich.description: The first time I saw one of these was, I think, in a riverside tavern in Vaslui during Red Harvest, I nearly spilled my ale laughing. Picture this, a sandwich with boiled eggs glaring up at you, stuck with sticks of celery on top, green and black olives set in the whites to give the “eyes” a hungry gleam. The tavernkeep had draped a slice of cucumber out the side like a lolling tongue, and the cheese, melted and oozed over the bread like crooked teeth. It’s meant to resemble a mimic, of course, and after a few tankards, when the room starts spinning, it’ll start looking unnervingly alive.

Mine Cart.name: Mine Cart
Mine Cart.description: Created for the sole purpose of removing debris from the mines, they can also be used to transport miners deeper to their working spots. They are usually carried back to the entrance at the end of the day by either commoners or livestock, but in some areas rope-haulage systems have been developed to make pulling easier.

Mine Rails.name: Mine Rails
Mine Rails.description: Made out of steel to sustain the heavy loads from carts carrying ore and rocks. Blacksmiths, when crafting these, are required to use the most pristine materials they have in stock to ensure they stand the test of time and do not bend under extreme pressures and temperatures.

Mishanite.name: Mishanite
Mishanite.description: Mishanite is a uniquely sought-after gem, much like Harumite. Those who seek it can mold it into any desired shape or color, and multiple manifestations can coexist. Despite its lack of tangible value to others, Mishanite holds immense sentimental significance. Finding this gem evokes a profound sense of personal warmth and closeness.

Mistletoe.name: Mistletoe
Mistletoe.description: Mistletoe is culturally referred to as the kissing plant, for the way it grows as well as being associated with some winter holidays. Mistletoe represents romance, fertility, and vitality. They grow attached to their host tree or shrub through which they extract water and nutrients from the host plant. Used by herbalists everywhere, for blood conditions, such as arthritis, or for those who have conjugal issues in their homes.

Mixed Jellied Fruits.name: Mixed Jellied Fruits
Mixed Jellied Fruits.description: Gelatin is created from isinglass, mainly harvested from fish, or it can also be made from animal bones. Fruits and sugar are added to the mixture and after cooling, it is cut into shapes and then served.

Moldavite.name: Moldavite
Moldavite.description: Moldavite is one of the most intriguing gems. It is said that this gem came from the skies long ago from a gigantic rock, yet no records of this specific event were made or survived the ages to confirm.

Moldavite Ring.name: Moldavite Ring
Moldavite Ring.description: Moldavite, a stone believed to have originated from celestial impacts, possesses a naturally glassy structure that allows it to be easily shaped into various implements such as rings or pendants. Some superstitious commoners claim that wearing moldavite jewelry significantly aids in healing otherwise incurable diseases, though these assertions remain unsupported by herbalists or alchemists.

Mole Rat Hide.name: Mole Rat Hide
Mole Rat Hide.description: Some say that this is a hide out from another world, however, mole rats are quite common around desert areas. Not a mole and not a rat, the mole-rat is one of the realm's most unusual rodents, however, their pelts do fetch quite a pretty penny due to their regional exclusivity.

Moleskin.name: Moleskin
Moleskin.description: A heavy cotton fabric which got its name due to the soft feeling to the touch, which bears similarity to mole's fur. The most common use of moleskin is for creating trousers, however, it is also usually a prime material for bandaging.

Monel.name: Monel
Monel.description: Monel is created by combining nickel and copper, and it has minimal iron content. It boasts exceptional corrosion resistance, making it suitable for a wide range of applications. Whether it's for dog tags, piping, metal sheets, or nails used in saltwater ships, objects made from this alloy typically exhibit extended durability.

Monkey Paw.name: Monkey Paw
Monkey Paw.description: Monkey Paw... this paw grants wishes. Each finger stands for one, and once a wish is spent, the finger locks tight, stiff as bone. It gives you what you asked for, aye, but it takes the spirit of your words and twists it like a rope. I knew a caravan master who begged for endless gold. He got it, but it rained from the skies as molten coins, burning his camp to ash. By the time you’re on the last finger, most folk would sooner beg for death than ask another boon.

Monster Pie.name: Monster Pie
Monster Pie.description: Don’t let the name fool you into thinking it’s something grisly like ogre or troll kidney. No, it’s just a pastry, and a festive one at that. A golden crust, brushed with butter till it gleams, filled to bursting with red berries. Cooks and bakers slice crude eyes and a jagged mouth into the crust so it grins at you with wicked cheer. Some faces come out goofy, some downright ghastly, and I swear the best tasting ones look like they’re about to bite back.

Monstrous Monsters.name: Monstrous Monsters
Monstrous Monsters.description: Monstrous Monsters is a small manual offered by tavernkeepers to travelers, adventurers, caravaners, and merchants alike. It provides a detailed list of monsters found in the area, steps that can be taken to avoid them, and advice on how to succeed in combat if engaged, or what actions to take until help arrives. Not enough credit is provided to tavernkeepers, who often hear the latest news and rumors and compile and write these manuals to help protect their patrons and maintain safe trade routes.

Moonshine.name: Moonshine
Moonshine.description: Moonshine is a homemade, unaged strong liquor. It is speculated that moonshine can either give you perfect eyesight or cause you to lose it entirely. However, all records tend to be inaccurate as this information is gathered after the consumption of the drink.

Moonstone.name: Moonstone
Moonstone.description:
"There's a legend that lycanthropes, just at the mere sight of this stone, are forced to shape-shift. Quite fascinating, indeed."

It is one of the most affordable gemstones in circulation and in some societies it is sewn into garments as a charm.

Morganite.name: Morganite
Morganite.description: Morganite stands out for its multifaceted utility, harnessing a blend of arcane attributes reminiscent of both emerald and aquamarine. This distinctive combination makes it highly prized among gem enthusiasts.

Morion.name: Morion
Morion.description: Also known as Smoky Quartz. One of the rarer forms of quartz. Due to it being almost opaque, it does have some similar proprieties to the Rose Quartz. It's usually sought after by nefarious people as it is mainly used in necromancy. When bones are infused with Moriom they become as hard as steel.

Morning Breeze.name: Morning Breeze
Morning Breeze.description: This non-alcoholic beverage is quite refreshing. Primarily made from cold-brewing tea, it has lemon and mint for flavors, and a single spoonful of sugar. When served in the morning, especially as sunlight filters through the glass, it takes on a wondrous golden glow and is also believed that it can cure all hangovers.

Mugwort.name: Mugwort
Mugwort.description: A common herb that is a favorite by herbalists everywhere. As a plant, it is easy to come-by as it grows in all biomes, and is used to resolve digestive problems, used for sedation, even as a laxative for the upset stomach.

Mule.name: Mule
Mule.description: Mules, widely used as working animals in the realms, are highly prized for their hardiness and docile nature. Their strength for their size and superior physical endurance compared to most horses, coupled with the ability to survive extreme weather, increased patience, and longer lifespan, make them a favorite choice for traveling very long distances.

Mulled Wine.name: Mulled Wine
Mulled Wine.description: Mulled wine becomes a staple drink as the colder seasons begin. The wine is boiled and then infused with sugar, black pepper, cinnamon, cloves, and orange peels. Served hot, it is rumored to cure the common cold, though it is primarily enjoyed for its warming effect.

Murder Cake.name: Murder Cake
Murder Cake.description: These I first encountered this cake at a masquerade in Sibiu, during Red Harvest, where the nobility have a taste for games that would curl the toes of a honest fisher. A Murder Cake is no simple dessert, it's the centerpiece of a theatrical evening where guests play at being detectives and killers. The cake itself is a grand, multi-tiered affair, often dark as a starless night with frosting the colour of old blood or fashioned to look like a gothic manor, but it also can be as simple as, a layer of cake with jam and a knife sticking out of it.

Murum.name: Murum
Murum.description: Murum finds application in various heavy-duty tasks such as plinth filling, road pavements, backfilling in trenches, and footing pits. Its absence of organic matter and ease of compaction, leading to the formation of durable surfaces, make it an ideal soil for construction purposes.

Mussel.name: Mussel
Mussel.description: Mussels are considered a delicacy in most regions, and they tend to be harvested from both freshwater and saltwater sources, primarily during the cold seasons, as they are at their prime at that time. They end up in a plethora of recipes, one of the most famous being beachside paella.

Mutton Snapper.name: Mutton Snapper
Mutton Snapper.description: Mutton Snapper capture isn’t just about luck, it’s also about having the right gear. Due to their strong, sudden bursts of energy, they require a durable rod, usually reinforced with metal. However, they are overall easy fish to catch with the proper tools. The Snapper fish can be pan-fried, baked, crumbed, broiled, barbequed, grilled, oven-fried, and even steamed, matching every taste. Fishermen often joke that there are more ways to cook a Mutton Snapper than there are ways to catch one.

Myrica Gale.name: Myrica Gale
Myrica Gale.description: Or more commonly known as Sweet gale. It can live in some of the most challenging conditions and is a very well-known and harvested plant. Its uses can range from local home remedies for stomach aches, and insect repellent, to creating flavorful teas, or even sweet ales.

Myrrh.name: Myrrh
Myrrh.description: Herbalists look for Myrrh resin to use in creating perfume, incense, and medicine. It is believed that if the leaf of the Myrrh is chewed on, it even helps with bad breath. In some cultures, it is also mixed in the process of making wine.

Mystery Soup.name: Mystery Soup
Mystery Soup.description: Similar to Meat of the Hunt, this soup is made from the leftovers of the day's hunt. It is mostly offered as a challenge for adventurers who claim they can eat anything without repercussions or as a hazing ritual for new patrons, providing amusement for the tavern keeper and other guests, as the new comers don't know better.

Nails.name: Nails
Nails.description: Nails are commonly made out of bronze or iron, and are mainly used as fasteners in construction, from small roofing nails to large iron spikes. They are also occasionally made out of copper or steel, particularly in environments where corrosion resistance is a key factor, such as coastal or riverside areas.

Natron.name: Natron
Natron.description: Natron is harvested directly as a salt mixture from dry salt lake beds, and it has multiple applications by both Alchemist and Herbalists. Herbalists mix Natron with herbs to treat minor wounds and cuts, while Alchemists use it as a binding agent for the more corrosive or explosive tinctures they create.

Neon-Ront.name: Neon-Ront
Neon-Ront.description: The Neon-Ront mushroom is located in the densest woodlands, where the light of the sun doesn't protrude from the dense foliage. The Neon-Ront mushroom can be located due to its blue light glow. This specific fungus is in high demand for many civilizations that live underground, as it can be used for shelving as it is quite sturdy, binds well with rocky terrain and walls, and can be cut into any shape. It is also used for indoor illumination.

Nephrite.name: Nephrite
Nephrite.description: Nephrite, similar in color, form, and shape to Jadeite, is predominantly utilized for stone carving and occasionally serves as a marble substitute in sculptures. Historically mined for ages, it is now frequently discovered in ancient, abandoned tombs.

Nerium.name: Nerium
Nerium.description: Most commonly known as Oleander, it is a small shrub used for gardening ornamentation. When used by highly skilled herbalists, they can make sleeping tinctures and cure some types of skin irritations.

Nettle.name: Nettle
Nettle.description: Or Stinging Nettle, it is used mainly by practitioners of medicine to help treat muscle pains of the weary adventurers or the joints of the elderly. Experienced Alchemists use them in potions of healing as one of the base ingredients

Nickel Ingot.name: Nickel Ingot
Nickel Ingot.description: A nickel ingot is a small, perfectly formed bar of pure nickel. It is said to be incredibly dense and heavy, and can only be forged by the most skilled blacksmiths. The metal has a shiny, silver color that glimmers in the light, and is an incredibly resilient metal, able to withstand even the strongest blows. Many tales and legends surround this rare and valuable metal, with some claiming that it holds magical properties and can bestow objects with incredible strength and durability, however in most regions it’s main purpose is for the creation of multiple types of coinage.

Nickel Ore.name: Nickel Ore
Nickel Ore.description: Nickel ore is a rare and prized mineral that can only be found deep within the earth.  It is said to be incredibly strong and durable, making it highly demanded metal by blacksmiths and craftsmen alike

Night Fangs.name: Night Fangs
Night Fangs.description: These fangs are a currency for all the night hunters, traded for specialized weaponry. The hunters hunt the creatures of the night, and after the hunt, even if they don't kill the captured creature, they remove their feeding fangs, rendering them harmless.

Nippers.name: Nippers
Nippers.description: Crafted mainly from steel, also referred to as farrier nippers, mirror the appearance of a giant pair of nail clippers. Their primary function involves removing a previously placed horseshoe. Beyond that, these tools prove adept at cutting the flat end of bolts or nails, resulting in a smoother finish for armor, furniture, or even walls.

No Backsies.name: No Backsies
No Backsies.description: No Backsies is a distinct golden wheat beer brewed exclusively by The Dead Deer Company. It is a golden wheat beer with notes of clove and banana, made according to traditional and unique brewing techniques, that are not disclosed to the regular commoner. Can only be found in the most distinguished taverns or inns, making it a rare find.

Novaculite.name: Novaculite
Novaculite.description: Novaculite, resembling quartz, fulfills highly specialized roles. Originally utilized for crafting arrow and spear points, it has since gained prominence as the primary material for manufacturing sharpening stones, essential in the production of whetstones.

Nutmeg.name: Nutmeg
Nutmeg.description: Nutmeg is the seed or the ground spice derived from the seed, of several tree species. Nutmeg and Mace the red cover of the nutmeg seed, is used to flavor baked goods, meat, fish, and vegetables, and in preserving and pickling or for seasonal beverages such as eggnog, mulled cider, and mulled wine. Herbalists use Nutmeg as it may help relieve bloating, cramps, and upset stomachs due to food intolerance or allergies.

Oak Log.name: Oak Log
Oak Log.description: The logs are usually processed into lumber, however, it's also commonly used in bakeries, furnaces, or home fireplaces as kindle.

Oak Plank.name: Oak Plank
Oak Plank.description: An easy-to-work durable wood that is used with carpentry tools and is best to use when building furniture.

Obsidian.name: Obsidian
Obsidian.description: Lava when cooling, leaves behind huge lumps of Obsidian. This gem is used to make short-bladed weapons, tools, ornaments, kitchen wares, and mirrors. Some ill-reputed factions use a form of jagged edge rings created from obsidian to create small deep cuts into their intended targets.

Obsidian Ingot.name: Obsidian Ingot
Obsidian Ingot.description: An obsidian ingot is a small, expertly chiseled bar of pure obsidian. It is said to be incredibly dense and heavy, and can only be crafted by the most skilled blacksmiths. The metal has a deep, dark color that seems to absorb light, but when struck, it glows with a fiery inner light.

Ochre Fish.name: Ochre Fish
Ochre Fish.description: Ochre Fish is a transparent type of fish, somewhat acidic and sticky to the touch, known to corrode most hooks when captured. Usually found in seas and oceans that are not disturbed by ship traffic. Capturing this fish is associated with bad omens, for more experienced fishermen, as whole schools of the Ochre Fish have a tendency to stick themselves to the belly of fishing boats, slowly corroding the material and sinking them. Experiments have been conducted to refine its acidic secretion into potent solvents or even weapons by alchemists.

Oil Lamp.name: Oil Lamp
Oil Lamp.description: They work in the same way as a candle but with fuel that is liquid at room temperature, so that a container for the oil is required. A textile wick drops down into the oil, and is lit at the end, burning the oil as it is drawn up the wick. Sources of fuel for oil lamps include a wide variety of plants such as nuts and seeds but also widely used are animal fats.

Oligoclase.name: Oligoclase
Oligoclase.description: Oligoclase being a semi-precious stone is usually in high demand by most commoners as it is one of the more affordable gems. It usually comes in either white, grey, green or red. Due to the wide range of colors

Olive Pomace.name: Olive Pomace
Olive Pomace.description: After olives are crushed for oil, the remnants are pressed again to extract any remaining oil and then dried into a fine powder. For ease of transportation, the powder is shaped into small pellets or cylindrical bricks. These bricks are used as fuel in bakeries, as their unique burning smell, combined with the aroma of baked goods, attracts considerable clientele and other establishments. Manors, castles, and forts often order them in large quantities for their braziers due to their long burn time. However, they are highly flammable and can ignite in direct sunlight, necessitating specific storage. They require storage in barrels with salted water to prevent mold and mitigate the fire risk.

Olives.name: Olives
Olives.description: The only difference between green and any other type of olives is the ripeness. Aside from being used as a garnish for salads or as a small snack, olives are turned into olive oil. They are first roasted and then left to dry in the sun before being taken to the mill for processing.

Olivine.name: Olivine
Olivine.description: Found widely across many regions, this gemstone sees little use in jewelry due to its brittle composition, which makes it prone to shattering. Instead, it is frequently pulverized into fine dust, serving as a substitute for sand in the realm of blacksmithing.

Olykoeks.name: Olykoeks
Olykoeks.description: They are known as oily cakes, or more commonly known as doughnuts, are a beloved pastry enjoyed by many, are a popular treat enjoyed by people all over the planes. The sweetened dough is dipped in hot oil for roughly 2 minutes, then taken out and topped with powdered sugar, jams, sweet cocoa paste, or even thin slices of fruit while still hot. Making this one of the most produced item by most bakeries, this pastry is a popular accompaniment to morning beverages or enjoyed by young folk with every meal.

On the Making of New Potions - A Newbie.name: On the Making of New Potions - A Newbie Alchemist Guide to Potion brewing
On the Making of New Potions - A Newbie.description: A beginner alchemist’s book, filled with detailed instructions on how to brew potions and including a few recipes on the last pages. It explains which alembics are preferable depending on what needs to be distilled and identifies common ingredients that work best as potion bases. The book is structured to gradually build the reader's skills, starting with simple mixtures and moving toward more complex brewing techniques.

Onion.name: Onion
Onion.description: Onions are cultivated and used around the world. As a food item, they are usually served cooked as part of a prepared savory dish, but can also be eaten raw or used to make pickles or chutneys. They are pungent when chopped and some types of onion may irritate the eyes.

Onion Sprout.name: Onion Sprout
Onion Sprout.description: A sprouting onion won't grow more onions in the current year. Instead, it will eventually flower and begin seeding. Afterward, the seeds can grow onions for the following year. By separating the sprouts inside an onion's layers and planting them in good soil, you can produce multiple new onions within a single season.

Onyx.name: Onyx
Onyx.description: If you wear this stone unenchanted, Lady Luck is bound to frown upon you. An important intaglio stone, used as part of jewelry to seal official documents.

Opal.name: Opal
Opal.description:
"In a time when magical experimentation was still a thing, two mages decided to combine fire and lightning enchanted opals. A massive explosion occurred, and the two were never heard from again. Those attuned to magic, from time to time, can feel the reverberation of that explosion in their bones. In some places, it is now forbidden by law to combine the two." 

Being one of the most colorful gems, when the stone is cut so precisely, and in such a way that it provides a beautiful array of colors, it can sometimes be worth more than a Diamond. Mainly used in jewelry, like pendants and ring centerpieces.

Opal Earrings.name: Opal Earrings
Opal Earrings.description: Cut by experienced gemcutters and connected with silver implements, opal, being one of the most colorful gems, when cut so precisely and in such a way that it provides a beautiful array of colors, becomes a favorite among the middle to higher classes of citizens. Some arcane casters usually wear the earrings, as they can be used as a conduit for some magical spells in their repertoire.

Opuntia.name: Opuntia
Opuntia.description: Opuntia is known by various names, with Prickly Pear Fruit being the most common. If the outer layer of the fruit is not properly removed, ingesting glochids, tiny spines from the fruit, can cause discomfort in the throat, lips, and tongue, as these spines easily penetrate the skin. The seeds are also used to produce flour.

Orange.name: Orange
Orange.description: It is mainly used for orange juice or flavoring of baked goods or cakes, however, it is also used depending on the region, to create orange oil made from the peels. The peels can be used in gardening as well in the form of slug repellent.

Orchid Bream.name: Orchid Bream
Orchid Bream.description: Orchid Bream is a bronze-colored fish, with purple scales, found gathering in large shoals in lowland ponds, lakes, and slow-flowing rivers. While considered an esteemed food fish by experienced chefs, wild catches remain relatively modest, as the rest of the common folk are not very familiar with it or how best to prepare it.

Owl.name: Owl
Owl.description: Owls, symbols of wealth, prosperity, wisdom, good luck, and fortune, are sought after as pets by many nobles and individuals dabbling in the arcane arts. Those engaged in animal husbandry, successfully domesticating owls, soon realize their effectiveness in controlling rodent infestations.

Oyster.name: Oyster
Oyster.description: They are usually harvested for food and for their rare pearls. Wizards on occasion use their shells as magical components, however, the spell it is used for has been kept a secret. In times long past, there was word that rare green emerald oysters had existed as well, however, no one has seen one lately. Some Taverns offer Oysters as a delicacy depending on the region.

Oölite.name: Oölite
Oölite.description: Oölites, often nicknamed Cave Pearls, are typically found in caves and vary in colors such as green, white, or brown, depending on the cave's specific biome. Their primary uses are decorative, used either as ornaments or crushed to create vivid inks.

Painite.name: Painite
Painite.description: Painite is the rarest gem in the realms. Nobody has a specific price for it and some say it can buy entire kingdoms, while others say it has no value. So far, besides the ornamentation of jewelry pieces, no other uses have been found. Researchers do study these specific gems for their more arcane applications; however, no discoveries have been made as of yet.

Palladium.name: Palladium
Palladium.description: Palladium, with its lustrous white appearance, stands as a precious metal highly prized for its rarity and distinctive characteristics. Its notable usage in jewelry, especially as an alloy for crafting white gold.

Pallet.name: Pallet
Pallet.description: A standard bed made by carpenters for a good night's sleep usually consists of straw or hay covered with a sheet. This type of mattress is known as a palliasse or pallet, which is how it got its name.

Palo Verde.name: Palo Verde
Palo Verde.description: The Palo Verde tree can be easily recognized by its green-colored bark. This tree is typically harvested for its bark, which can be used for multiple purposes. The inner bark can be woven into rope or baskets, or used for making chair bottoms. Additionally, it is utilized for making canoes, and clothing, and as a surface for paintings and maps. The bark can also be used as shingles and wall coverings.

Pancakes.name: Pancakes
Pancakes.description: Eggs, milk, sugar, and flour are all it takes to make delicious pancakes. When topped with syrup or fruit, they become one of the most satisfying and sweet breakfasts offered by taverns.

Pandean Pipe.name: Pandean Pipe
Pandean Pipe.description: The Pandean pipe, often referred to as the pan flute or panpipe, is made from closed tubes of increasing lengths. Sound is produced when air is blown in its tubes, causing them to resonate and produce a unique sound. This instrument is widely used in music and traditional performances.

Papaya.name: Papaya
Papaya.description: The ripe fruit of the papaya is usually eaten raw, without skin or seeds. The Papaya fruit is also used to tenderize meats as they provide a very specific taste. Herbalists provide the leaves to be smoked as it is believed that they help with breathing, or have the leaves turned into a paste as a laxative.

Paradiso.name: Paradiso
Paradiso.description: Paradiso is a rare and distinct granite color, found only in a few locations throughout the realms. It is in high demand but short supply, often causing regional prices to skyrocket. Its rich purple hue gives it a premium appearance, making it an exquisite choice for indoor furniture such as countertops and tables.

Paring Chisel.name: Paring Chisel
